chat_history.content: : Welcome to Conceptual Academy! I'm Alia, and I'm here to support the learning of core science concepts. Let's get started. How can I help you today?

: Hi Alia. I'm taking an environmental science course this semester. We're studying agriculture, and I need to learn about pesticides. To be honest, science has never been my strong point, but I'm trying to do better in college.

: I'm glad you're engaging with the material! Today we can explore pesticides in agriculture - what they are, how they work, and their environmental impacts. Pesticides are substances used to control pests that threaten crops. Would you like to begin by understanding the different types of pesticides?
: Sure. I guess I always thought pesticides just meant bug killers, but there must be more to it?

: Exactly! Pesticides are a broader category than many people realize. They include several specific types: insecticides that kill insects, herbicides that kill weeds, and fungicides that kill fungi. Farmers use these different pesticides to defend their crops against various natural enemies that can reduce crop yields.
: Oh, that makes sense. So not all bugs are bad for crops, right? I've heard bees are important.

: That's a great observation! Most species of insects are actually beneficial or even essential to agriculture. Honeybees, for example, are responsible for the pollination of $10 billion worth of produce in the United States. Countless other insect species take part in nutrient recycling and help maintain soil quality. Only a small minority of insect species threaten our ability to grow, harvest, and store crops, and it's these specific species that insecticides target.
: So what are insecticides made of? I'm picturing some pretty harsh chemicals.

: You're on the right track. The most widely used insecticides fall into three main chemical categories: chlorinated hydrocarbons, organophosphorus compounds, and carbamates. Chlorinated hydrocarbons have a remarkable persistence - they can kill insects for months or even years on treated surfaces.
: Months or years? That seems like a really long time. Why do they last so long?

: There are two main reasons for their persistence. First, chlorinated hydrocarbons tend to be nonbiodegradable, which means there are no natural pathways to break them down chemically. Second, they are nonpolar compounds, which means they're insoluble in water and thus aren't washed away by rainwater.
: That doesn't sound very eco-friendly. Can you give an example of one of these chlorinated hydrocarbons?

: A prime example is DDT, which stands for dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane. In 1939, there was a breakthrough in insect pest control with the chemical synthesis of this chlorinated hydrocarbon. During the 1940s and 1950s, DDT was applied liberally to crops, resulting in markedly greater yields.
: Oh, I think I've heard of DDT! Wasn't it banned because it was harmful?

: You're right that DDT was eventually banned in many countries, but it's important to understand its full history. DDT not only protected plants but also protected people from disease. It was applied to rivers, streams, and villages to help control the proliferation of mosquitoes, lice, and tsetse flies, which spread malaria, typhus, and sleeping sickness, respectively. According to the World Health Organization, by protecting against these diseases, DDT has saved an estimated 25 million human lives.
: Wow, I had no idea it saved so many lives. So why was it banned then?

: There were several issues that emerged with DDT use. Insect populations began to develop resistance to DDT within a few years of its first application. Additionally, DDT was found to be toxic to wildlife, including the natural predators of insects, such as birds. With fewer natural predators, DDT-resistant insects were able to thrive. The early increased crop yields resulting from DDT use were therefore not sustainable in the long term.
: I see. So it was initially successful but then created new problems.

: Exactly. In the 1950s and 1960s, these and other negative aspects of DDT and other pesticides were brought to the public's attention by various publications, including biologist Rachel Carson's book "Silent Spring." Carson described the importance of understanding the dynamics of ecosystems, most of which are highly sensitive to human activities.
: What kind of negative effects did DDT have on wildlife specifically?

: One of the most significant effects Carson described was a phenomenon known as bioaccumulation. This is where a toxic chemical that enters a food chain at a low trophic level becomes more concentrated in organisms higher up the chain.

For example, in bodies of water sprayed with DDT, small amounts of the pesticide were ingested and stored in the nonpolar lipids of aquatic microorganisms. Since these microorganisms serve as food for animals at higher trophic levels, DDT became more concentrated in the body fat of these larger creatures. Predatory birds at the top of the chain accumulated the greatest amounts of DDT.
: So the higher up the food chain, the more DDT accumulated? That sounds dangerous.

: That's correct. The DDT concentration in a food chain can be magnified from 0.000003 parts per million as a pollutant in the water to 25 parts per million in a bird at the top of the chain. Eventually, these elevated DDT levels affected bird populations because the egg shells of affected birds became too thin and fragile to support the growing chick embryos. DDT contributed to the decline of many bird populations and the near extinction of some species of ospreys, hawks, eagles, and falcons.
: So if I understand correctly, a tiny amount in the water became a dangerous amount in birds? That's scary. This makes me wonder - are fish-eating birds affected worse than other animals?

: That's an excellent question that shows you're understanding the concept of bioaccumulation! Fish-eating birds are indeed more susceptible to DDT contamination compared to, say, plankton-eating fish. Here's why: A plankton-eating fish gets DDT from all the plankton it eats. This same DDT then enters the bird that eats this fish. But because the bird eats many fish, its exposure to DDT is amplified.
: That makes sense. Did we develop safer alternatives after DDT was banned?

: Yes, in the early 1970s, the United States and many other countries banned the use of DDT, and within a matter of years, many wildlife species in these countries were able to recover. Additionally, many chlorinated hydrocarbon alternatives to DDT were developed. One of the earliest substitutes was methoxychlor. This compound has much lower toxicity in most animals and, unlike DDT, is not readily stored in animal fat.
: What made methoxychlor safer than DDT?

: If you look carefully at the structures of methoxychlor and DDT, they are identical except that methoxychlor has two ether groups whereas DDT has two chlorine atoms. Because the structures are nearly identical, they have nearly the same level of toxicity in insects. In higher animals, however, the oxygen atoms facilitate detoxification. Specifically, enzymes in the liver cleave the ether groups to synthesize polar products that are readily excreted through the kidneys.
: Oh, I'm not great with chemical structures, but it sounds like a small change made it much safer for non-target animals?

: Precisely! Small changes in chemical structure can dramatically alter how a compound interacts with different biological systems. Now, let's discuss the other types of insecticides I mentioned earlier: organophosphorus compounds and carbamates.
: Are those safer alternatives too?

: They're different in important ways. Organophosphorus compounds and carbamates, in contrast to chlorinated hydrocarbons, readily decompose to water-soluble components and so do not act over extended periods of time. Their immediate toxicity to both insects and animals is much greater than that of chlorinated hydrocarbons, however. Added safety precautions are required during their application, especially because of their toxicity to honeybees.
: That's concerning about honeybees. Is there any way to use these without harming bees?

: Yes, there are application strategies to minimize bee exposure. Honeybees do not forage at night, so quick-acting pesticides such as organophosphorus compounds and carbamates are best applied in the evening. By the time the bees return the next day, these pesticides have lost much of their toxicity.
: That's smart! Can you give me examples of these types of pesticides?

: There are hundreds of organophosphorus and carbamate insecticides in agricultural and household use. Two important examples are malathion, an organophosphorus compound, and carbaryl, a carbamate. Malathion kills a variety of insects, such as aphids, leafhoppers, beetles, and spider mites. Carbaryl, like many other carbamates, is relatively selective in the types of insects that it kills.
: Are there any newer insecticides that are being used today?

: Yes, the most widely used insecticides today are actually the neonicotinoids, such as the compound imidacloprid. These compounds are derivatives of nicotine, which is a naturally occurring neurotoxin to both insects and mammals. The neonicotinoids, however, are selectively more toxic to insects than they are to mammals, making them safer for humans to handle.
: Did you say nicotine? Like from cigarettes?

: Yes, exactly! Neonicotinoids are chemically related to the nicotine found in tobacco. These compounds tend to be water-soluble and can be added to irrigation water or even sprayed on seeds, which grow into plants that then retain enough neonicotinoids to fight off insects. They're also biodegradable, especially when exposed to sunlight.
: That sounds promising. Are there any downsides to neonicotinoids?

: Unfortunately, yes. There is strong evidence that these compounds are having a negative impact on bee populations. They may be responsible, in part, for a phenomenon called colony collapse disorder, where entire bee colonies mysteriously die off.
: That's concerning. Let's switch topics - can you tell me about herbicides? How do they work?

: Of course. Herbicides are used to kill weeds, which compete with crop plants for valuable nutrients. The traditional method for controlling weeds is to plow them under the soil, where in decomposing, they release the nutrients they absorbed while they were alive.
: Is plowing a good solution for dealing with weeds?

: Plowing does have benefits - it aerates the soil and returns nutrients. However, it's either labor-intensive or energy-intensive and can lead to topsoil erosion, which is a significant disadvantage.
: So herbicides are a more efficient alternative to plowing?

: In many cases, yes. In the early 1900s, farmers noted that certain fertilizers, such as calcium cyanamide (CaNCN), selectively kill weeds while causing little harm to crops. This prompted a broad search for chemicals that act as herbicides. Today, a farmer can choose from hundreds of herbicides, many tailored for a specific weed. Farmers in the United States apply millions of pounds of herbicides annually.
: Can you give me examples of common herbicides?

: Two selective herbicides are the carboxylic acids 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) and 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4,5-T). Both mimic the action of plant growth hormones and are selective in killing broad-leafed plants but not grass-like crops such as corn and wheat.
: Why are they called "selective" herbicides?

: They're called selective because they target specific types of plants while leaving others unharmed. This selectivity is very valuable in agriculture because it allows farmers to kill weeds without damaging their crops.
: Wait, I think I've heard of something called Agent Orange from the Vietnam War. Is that related to these herbicides?

: You're right to make that connection. A herbicide known as Agent Orange is a blend of 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T. During the Vietnam War, U.S. military forces applied more than 15 million gallons of Agent Orange and related herbicides in an effort to defoliate jungle areas that could harbor enemy troops.

Unfortunately, health problems in Vietnamese troops and civilians, U.S. troops, and others exposed to Agent Orange have since been linked to a minor contaminant of the herbicide—the highly toxic compound 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD). This contaminant was generated as a side product in the manufacture of 2,4,5-T.
: That's awful. Is 2,4,5-T still used today?

: In 1985, because of this contamination, the use of 2,4,5-T was prohibited by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. However, TCDD-free methods of 2,4,5-T production have since been developed, which raises the possibility that 2,4,5-T may once again be introduced as an effective herbicide.
: Are there other herbicides in common use today?

: Yes, three other commonly used herbicides are atrazine, paraquat, and glyphosate. Atrazine is toxic to common weeds but not to many grass-like crops, which can rapidly detoxify this herbicide through metabolism.

Paraquat kills weeds in their sprouting phase. During the 1970s and 1980s, this herbicide was sprayed aerially to destroy drug-producing poppy and marijuana fields in the United States, Mexico, and much of Central and South America. However, paraquat residues made their way into the illicit drug products, causing lung damage in users. So, for ethical reasons, the spraying of paraquat on drug-producing plants is no longer common practice.
: I think I've heard of glyphosate - isn't that Roundup? I see it at the garden store.

: That's correct! Glyphosate is the active ingredient in Roundup. It's a nonselective herbicide that affects a biochemical process common to all plants—the biosynthesis of the amino acids tyrosine and phenylalanine. Glyphosate has low toxicity in animals because most animals do not synthesize these amino acids, obtaining them from food instead. However, it's worth noting that long-term exposure is associated with an increased risk for certain types of blood cancers.
: We've talked about insecticides and herbicides. What about the third type you mentioned - fungicides?

: Fungicides are important pesticides as well. As decomposers, fungi play an important role in soil formation, but they can also harm crops. Most of the harm they cause occurs during a plant's early growth stages. Fungi can also spoil stored food and are particularly devastating to the world's fruit harvest.

In the United States, fungicides rank third after herbicides and insecticides in the amounts used. An example of a fungicide is thiram, which is widely used on fruits and vegetables.

: So to summarize, pesticides include insecticides, herbicides, and fungicides, and each type targets different agricultural pests. But they all seem to have potential environmental or health impacts too.

: That's an excellent summary! During the last 60 years, pesticides have benefited our society by preventing disease and increasing food production. Our need for pesticides will continue, but greater specificity will certainly be demanded. Furthermore, it is becoming increasingly apparent that the benefits of using pesticides must be considered in the context of potential risks.

: This has really helped me understand pesticides better. It seems like there's a constant balance between their agricultural benefits and their environmental impacts. I used to think science topics like this were too complicated for me, but breaking it down this way makes it much clearer.

: I'm glad you found this helpful! You've demonstrated a good understanding of the complex issues surrounding pesticide use. Science is all about understanding these kinds of balances and trade-offs. Is there anything else about pesticides or agricultural practices you'd like to explore further?
: Not right now. This gives me a good foundation for my environmental science class. Thanks for helping me understand this topic!

: You're very welcome! Remember that science is accessible to everyone, regardless of your background. You've shown great critical thinking skills today. Feel free to come back anytime you want to explore more science concepts!
